"Victim blaming" is one of the many misunderstood concepts in infosec.

1094367354002247681.text:
Quick thought about this advice. Every time it's offered, people claim it's victim shaming. I disagree. It's threat modeling.

We regularly tell orgs not to generate data they won't protect. We tell them to retain data no longer than they need it. This is good advice. 1/2https://twitter.com/Vhicck/status/1094008854105473030 …

1114339035449704448.text: I'll talk to my kids all day long about this stuff, but I'll never install the sorts of software or buy the kinds of tracking devices I keep seeing peddled. These things are consistently absolute rubbish and they prey on scared and uninformed parents and teachers to get traction.

1114339034199801856.text: And accept that they're going to see porn. They're going to swear in chats. They're going to talk to people you don't like. And 90%+ of the time, they're more technically adept than their parents and will know how to hide it and circumvent the parental controls.

1114339032958259200.text: You worried about your kids online? Talk to them. Browse the web with them. Introduce them to the wonders of the web on your terms and *physically* monitor them (you know, like exist together in the same room for a bit).

1114339031720943616.text: The problem is that you've got a bunch of technically illiterate parents (understandable) being pushed things by schools that are influenced by marketers (much less understandable) and built with near zero focus on security (inexcusable).

1114339030496206848.text: I've been looking at a bunch of kid-related devices and services lately, mostly relating to how parents can monitor and control their activities. It's just consistently horrifyingly bad; FUD-ridden at best, massive privacy violations at worst (i.e. data accessible to the public).

1084909528510939136.text: For anyone interested in a well-balanced overview of what’s going on, have a read of this piece by @stilgherrian which focuses far more on the facts than the clickbait headlines:https://www.zdnet.com/article/whats-actually-in-australias-encryption-laws-everything-you-need-to-know/ …

1084909526795530240.text: For example, when the bill was being rushed through we kept hearing that “we need to keep Australians safe before Xmas”. Huh? The political spin on it was just unbearable to watch and it dominated the headlines whilst he rational discussion was held quietly in side channels.

1084909522806697984.text: The thing that most frustrates me most about this AA bill is not the contents of it (and some of it is damn concerning), it’s that both sides of the fence (government and privacy advocates), continue to massively misrepresent reality through emotive language.

1084909518474031104.text: It’s an absolutely ridiculous headline and the first sentence only goes downhill from there: “Australia is now the first Western nation to ban security”. Anyone with an inkling of common sense can see that doesn’t pass the bullshit test.

1084909513981943808.text: A few people just pointed me to this story from @ExtremeTech on “Australia Becomes First Western Nation to Ban Secure Encryption” and asked for opinions. It’s from last month but seems to be getting traction again today:https://www.extremetech.com/internet/281991-australia-becomes-first-western-nation-to-ban-secure-encryption …
